LTTextBox.text: INTRODUCTION
This document is the final report on work carried out on those parts of Exploration License E59/907
being  relinquished  as  part  of  the  compulsory  partial  relinquishment  required  for  this  lease.  This
license forms part of the Windimurra Project, which is located in Central Western Australia, with
leases  covering  parts  of  the  Narndee  Intrusion  and  the  southern  portion  of  the  Windimurra
Intrusion.  The  project  is  being  managed  by  WMC  in  joint  venture  with  Apex  Minerals  NL.  WMC
entered  into  the  joint  venture  in    April  2004.  The  joint  venture  includes  4  Exploration  Licenses
(E57/529,  E59/907,  E59/1079,  E59/1096)  and  one  Exploration  Licence  under  application
(E59/1086). The area was selected for potential nickel-copper-PGE mineralisation associated with
feeders to the Narndee and Windimurra Intrusions. Figure 1 shows the location of the WMC-Apex
Windimurra project.
Field work carried out on the surrendered portion of the lease included acquiring airmag data, lag
geochemical and gravity surveys, as well as a reconnaissance field trip.
TENEMENT HOLDING
Exploration Licence E59/907 is subject to a Farm In and Joint Venture Agreement between Apex
Minerals NL and Windimurra Resources Pty Ltd, with Apex managing the leases and earning 80%.
WMC has entered into a joint venture with these parties with the right to manage the project and
earn 70% if conditions of the joint venture are met. Table 1 details the tenement information for
that portion of the project to be relinquished. Figure 2 depicts Exploration Licence E59/907 and the
area to be relinquished overlying the graticular block outlines.
Table 1: Tenement Information on Portion to be Relinquished

GEOLOGY
The Windimurra Project covers rocks of the Windimurra and Narndee Complexes, which are large
mafic  intrusions close to a flexure and fault intersection on the archon-archon domain boundary
separating  the  Murchison  and  Southern  Cross  Domains.  They  have  been  interpreted  as  large,
layered  intrusions  of  gabbro,  anorthosite,  pyroxenite,  peridotite  and  magnetic  cumulates.  The
Windimurra Complex has a total outcrop area of 2,120 km2 and comprises hundreds of rhythmic
layers  of  gabbro,  dolerite,  gabbronorite,  anorthosite,  pyroxenite  and  magnetite  cumulates.  The
Narndee  Complex  sits  to  the  south  of  the  Windimurra,  and  consists  predominantly  of  repeated
cycles of peridotite/pyroxenite through to gabbro and gabbronorite.
For both complexes, a minimum Rb-Sr age date of 2669Ma has been constrained by felsic dykes
cutting  the  mafic  rocks,  with  a  Sm-Nd  age  date  of  2800Ma  recently  calculated.  The  complexes
have been intruded by granites, pegmatites and porphyritic dykes.
There is very little encouragement in either the aeromagnetics and/or the geochemistry that there
are  prospective  ultramafic  rocks  in  the  area  relinquished.  Outcrop  in  the  relinquished  portion  is
scarce, however granitic rocks have been mapped and interpreted as underlying much of the area.
The Windimurra Complex outcrops as gabbros in the north-east corner of the relinquished area.
Figure  3  shows  the  GSWA  mapped  geology  of  the  area,  topography  and  the  area  to  be
relinquished shaded blue.
Windimurra Partial Surrender Report E59/907
